description: A square temple in a temenos located on a low hill beside the river Stort. Lewis (1966) suggests a chronology ranging from the mid to late 3rd CE and ending in the late 4th or early 5th CE, but it now seems that it was a late Iron Age shrine succeeded by a masonry temple in the 80s CE.
bibliography: Martyn, Blick, Brindle, et al, (2015), Harlow (Essex), available at: https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449
Smith, A., (2008), The Fate of Pagan Temples in Sount-East Britain during the late and post-Roman periods., in Ritual Landscapes of Roman South-East Britain
France, N., Gobel, B., (1985), The Romano-British Temple at Harlow
(1963), Essex, in Victoria County History, 3, pg. 139 ff
